fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of degree of formal polynomials

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let p,q\in R[x_{1},…,x_{n}] be nonzero formal polynomials. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: If R is an integral domain, then \deg (fg)=\deg (f)+\deg (g)

fr:title.text: Ring of formal polynomials with coefficients in integral domain forms an integral domain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring of formal polynomials with coefficients in integral domain forms an integral domain

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be an Integral domain. Let x be a formal polynomial. Then the Polynomial ring R[x] is an integral domain.

Let R be a Commutative Ring, let x be a formal variable. We define the Ring of Formal Laurent Polynomials to be the ring R(x)=\{\sum ^{n}_{j=-k}a_{k}x^{k}\mid a_{j}\in R, a_{-k}\neq 0,a_{n}\neq 0, n,k\in \mathbb {N}_{0}\}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Caution: Terminology seems to vary wildly here. Some people reserve the term "Laurent polynomials" for the situation where n=\infty . I'm going to call these things Formal Laurent series and denote it by R(\mskip -3mu(x)\mskip -3mu) in analogy to R[{[x]}].

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring. Let x be a formal variable. The Ring of Formal Power Series R[{[x]}] consists of all formal power series f(x)=\sum ^{\infty }_{n=0}a_{n}x^{n} with addition defined by matching powers of x: \left (\sum _{n}a_{n}x^{n}\right )+\left (\sum _{m}b_{m}x^{m}\right )=\sum _{n}(a_{n}+b_{n})x^{n} and multiplication defined by Cauchy convolution product \left (\sum _{n}a_{n}x^{n}\right )\left (\sum _{m}b_{m}x^{m}\right )=\sum _{n=0}\left (\sum ^{n}_{k=0}a_{n-k}b_{k}\right )x^{n}. This is a unital ring when R is unital.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subring
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML c0sp1:def 3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring. A Subring of R is a ring S such that S\subseteq R and 0\in S and +_{R}|_{S}=+_{S} and \star _{R}|_{S}=\star _{S}. In other words, every element of S is an element of R, and R's binary operators restricted to S coincide with S's binary operators.
If R is a unital ring and 1\in S, then we say S is a Unital Subring of R.
We see \mathbb {Z}\subseteq \mathbb {Q}\subseteq \mathbb {R}\subseteq \mathbb {C}\subseteq \mathbb {H} are subrings.
Let n\in \mathbb {N} and R be a Ring. Then some common subrings of \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(R) include:

fr:ol.fr:li: Diagonal matrices form a subring
Upper-triangular matrices form a subring
Lower-triangular matrices form a subring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Exercise: Do the collection of orthogonal matrices form a subring or not?
Exercise: Do the collection of unitary matrices form a subring of \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {C}) or not?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Center of a Ring
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML weddwitt:def 4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring. The Center of R is the subring Z(R) consisting of z\in R such that for all r\in R we have zr=rz and also (for non-associative rings) for all r,s\in R and for all z\in Z(R) we have z(rs)=(zr)s and r(zs)=(rz)s and (rs)z=r(sz). In other words, Z(R) consists of elements which commute and associate with all elements of the ring.
Uniqueness: If there are two possible centers, it's obvious they contain the same elements, which means they are equal to each other.

Existence: We see that the underlying set is nonempty and well-defined. We just need to show it is closed under addition and multiplication and contains 0\in Z(R)...well, 0r=0=r0 for all r\in R, so 0\in Z(R).
We see for any z,w\in Z(R) that for all r\in R, (z+w)r=zr+wr=rz+rw=r(z+w) which means z+w\in Z(R). So it's closed under addition
We see for any z,w\in Z(R) that for all r\in R, (zw)r=z(wr)=(wr)z=(rw)z=r(wz)=r(zw) which means zw\in Z(R). So it's closed under multiplication.
Taken together, this means there exists a well-defined center Z(R) which is a subring of R.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: For associative rings R, we only need to check that zr=rz for all z\in Z(R) and for all r\in R, since it's associative.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Exercise: If R is unital, is 1\in Z(R) or not? Prove it.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring morphism
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3
Artin Algebra Section 11.3
Hungerford Algebra Section III.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R and S be Rings. We define a Ring Morphism (or just a Morphism if unambiguous) to be a function \varphi \colon R\to S such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Additive: for any x,y\in R we have \varphi (x+y)=\varphi (x)+\varphi (y)
Preserves zero: \varphi (0_{R})=0_{S}
Multiplicative: for any x,y\in R we have \varphi (xy)=\varphi (x)\varphi (y)
Preserves one (when between unital rings): \varphi (1_{R})=1_{S} when there is a 1_{R}\in R and 1_{S}\in S

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Exercise: Do we really need \varphi (0)=0 or is this a consequence of additivity?
Exercise: Do we really need \varphi (1_{R})=1_{S} or is this a consequence of the multiplicative property?

fr:title.text: Inclusion of factor into direct product

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inclusion of factor into direct product

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider i\colon \mathbb {Q}\hookrightarrow \mathbb {Q}\times \mathbb {Q} defined by i(x)=(x,0). We claim i is not a Ring morphism.
We see that i(1)=(1,0)\neq (1,1) so i cannot possibly be multiplicative.

fr:title.text: Not all rings have morphisms between them

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Not all rings have morphisms between them

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let p\in \mathbb {N} be prime. Then there is no ring morphism \varphi \colon \mathbb {F}_{p}\to \mathbb {Z} from any finite field to the integers.

Assume there were a ring morphism. Then \varphi (1+(p-1))=\varphi (1)+\varphi (p-1) by additivity, but \varphi (1+(p-1))=\varphi (p)=\varphi (0)=0, so we must have \varphi (1)+\varphi (p-1)=0 which then implies 0=\varphi (1)+\varphi (p)-\varphi (1)=\varphi (p). But this means p=\varphi (\sum ^{p}_{i=1}1)=0 which is a contradiction.

fr:title.text: Identity function is a ring morphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity function is a ring morphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring. Then \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{R}\colon R\to R is a Ring morphism.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of ring morphisms
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML ring_2:7
MML ring_2:8
MML ring_2:9

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R and S be Rings. Let \varphi \colon R\to S be a Ring morphism. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: For any x\in R, \varphi (-x)=-\varphi (x)
For any x,y\in R, \varphi (x-y)=\varphi (x)-\varphi (y)
If R is unital, then either \varphi (1)=1 or \varphi (1)=0.
For any ring T and Ring morphism \psi \colon S\to T, we see \psi \circ \varphi \colon R\to T is a ring morphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Left ideal of a ring
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML ideal_1:def 1
Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3
Artin Algebra Section 11.3
Hungerford Algebra Section III.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Ring. A Left Ideal of R is a nonempty subset I\subseteq R such that
for any r\in R and x\in I we have rx\in I; and
for any x,y\in I we have x+y\in I.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We could speak of ideals in more general settings, e.g., rings without negation.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right ideal of a ring
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML ideal_1:def 2
Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3
Artin Algebra Section 11.3
Hungerford Algebra Section III.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Ring. A Right Ideal of R is a nonempty subset I\subseteq R such that
for any r\in R and x\in I we have xr\in I; and
for any x,y\in I we have x+y\in I.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3
Artin Algebra Section 11.3
Hungerford Algebra Section III.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring. A (Two-Sided) Ideal of R is a nonempty subset I\subseteq R such that I is a left ideal and a right ideal of R.
Furthermore, when I\neq R we say I is a Proper (two-sided) ideal of R.

Some authors use the notation I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq }R to indicate I is an ideal of R, as well as I\mathrel {\triangleleft }R for proper ideals, analogous to the notation used for Normal subgroups.
(1) For commutative rings, any left ideal is also a right ideal, and so we just speak of "ideals".
(2) "Ideal" originally described "ideal elements" adjoined to a ring, which are not "real".
(3) A two-sided ideal forms a Subring of R, same for one-sided ideals of R.

(4) Traditionally, the historic notation used to indicate we're working with ideals was to use fraktur letters (\mathfrak {a}, \mathfrak {b}, \mathfrak {c}, and so on). This was a horrible decision. Modern conventions use I, J, and variants using apostrophes or indices.

fr:title.text: Collection of ideals forms a set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Collection of ideals forms a set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring. Then the collection of left/right/two-sided ideals of R forms a set.

Look at the set \mathcal {I}=\{I\in \mathcal {P}(R)\mid I\hbox { is an ideal}\}, where "is an ideal" means the subset is a left/right/two-sided ideal (depending on what the reader wants). This is clearly a subset of \mathcal {P}(R), which means \mathcal {I} is the set sought.
Let R be a Ring. Let I and J be left/right/two-sided ideals of R. Then we define their sum to be the left/right/two-sided ideal I+J=\{a+b\in R\mid a\in I,b\in J\}.

Let R be a Ring. Let I and J be left/right/two-sided ideals of R. Then we define their product to be the left/right/two-sided ideal consisting of all possible finite linear combinations IJ=\{a_{1}b_{1}+…+a_{n}b_{n}\in R\mid n\in \mathbb {N},a_{i}\in I,b_{i}\in J\hbox { for }i=1,…,n\}.

Let \varphi \colon R\to S be a Ring morphism. We define the Kernel of \varphi to be the (two-sided) Ideal \ker (\varphi ) of R defined by: for all x\in R we have x\in \ker (\varphi ) if and only if \varphi (x)=0.
Let R be any Ring. Then \{0\} gives us an Ideal of R called the Trivial Ideal.

fr:title.text: Intersection of ideals is an ideal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intersection of ideals is an ideal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring. Let I and J be left (resp., right, two-sided) ideals of R. Then I\cap J is a left (resp., right, two-sided) ideal of R.

fr:title.text: Division rings have trivial left ideals

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Division rings have trivial left ideals

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let D be a Division ring. Then the only left ideals of D are D itself and the Trivial ideal.
Let I be a left ideal of D. Let x\in I be nonzero x\neq 0. Then there exists a x^{-1}\in D such that x^{-1}x=1\in I and then all of D is contained in I.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quotient Ring
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.3.6
Artin Algebra Section 11.3
Hungerford Algebra Theorem III.2.7
MML ring_1:def 6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring and I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be an ring-0011 of R. Then the additive quotient group R/I is a ring under the following binary operators (r+I)+(s+I)=(r+s)+I and (r+I)(s+I)=(rs)+I for all r,s\in R.

Furthermore,
If R is commutative, then R/I is commutative.
If R is unital, then R/I is unital.

To prove well-definedness, we should prove R/I equipped with these operators form a ring (since existence and uniqueness follow from the quotient group). Specifically, that multiplication exists and satisfies the various axioms.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Canonical ring morphism
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML ring_2:def 7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring, let I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be an Ideal of R. The Canonical Morphism \pi \colon R\to R/I is defined by: for any a\in R, \pi (a)=a+I.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: There is no standard notation for the canonical morphism, and I was debating between \gamma (Greek lowercase "c" for "canonical") and \pi since it's a sort of projection.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R and S be Rings. A Ring Isomorphism from R to S is a Ring morphism \varphi \colon R\to S such that there exists a ring morphism \psi \colon S\to R satisfying \varphi \circ \psi =\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{S} and \psi \circ \varphi =\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{R}.
We say rings R and S are isomorphic (denoted R\cong S) if there exists a ring isomorphism \varphi \colon R\to S.
Let \varphi \colon R\to S be a Ring morphism. Then \varphi is a Ring Isomorphism if and only if \varphi is bijective.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: First Isomorphism Theorem for Rings
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML ring_2:15

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \varphi \colon R\to S be a Ring morphism. Then the following all holds:

fr:ol.fr:li: \ker (\varphi )\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R is an Ideal of R
\mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\varphi )\subseteq S is a Subring.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Canonical ring morphism of \ker (\varphi ) is the Ring Isomorphism being sought.
Let R be a Ring, let A\subseteq R be a Subring of R, and let I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be an Ideal of R. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: A+I\subseteq R is a subring
A/(A\cap I)\cong (A+I)/I with the isomorphism defined by a\mapsto a+I

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Only the first two results needs to be proven.
Let R be a Ring. Let I,J\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be Ideals of R. If I\subseteq J, then J / I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R / I and \frac {R / I}{J / I}\cong R / J.
Let R be a Ring. Then:

fr:ol.fr:li: A Left Principal Ideal of R is the ideal Ra=\{xa\in R\mid x\in R\} for some fixed a\in R.
A Right Principal Ideal of R is the ideal aR=\{ay\in R\mid y\in R\} for some fixed a\in R.
A Left Principal Ideal of R is the ideal RaR=\{xay\in R\mid x,y\in R\} for some fixed a\in R.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: When R is a Commutative Ring, all three notions coincide and we write (a) for the principal ideal generated by a.
Let R be a Ring.

fr:ol.fr:li: A Maximal Right Ideal is a proper right ideal I\subset R such that for any other right ideal J\subseteq R, if I\subseteq J then either I=J or J=R.
A Maximal Left Ideal is a proper left ideal I\subset R such that for any other left ideal J\subseteq R, if I\subseteq J then either I=J or J=R.
A Maximal (Two-Sided) Ideal is a proper ideal I\mathrel {\triangleleft } R such that for any other ideal J\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R, if I\subseteq J then either I=J or J=R.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: When we drop the condition that I is proper, then we have a Quasi-Maximal left/right/two-sided ideal.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: For commutative rings R, all three notions coincide.

fr:title.text: Ideal is maximal iff quotient ring is field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal is maximal iff quotient ring is field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.4.12

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let M\mathrel {\triangleleft } R be an ideal. Then M is Maximal ideal if and only if the Quotient Ring R/M is a Field.
Let R be a Commutative Ring. An ideal P\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R is Quasi-Prime if for any a,b\in R such that ab\in P, then either a\in P or b\in P.
If P\mathrel {\triangleleft } R is a proper quasi-prime ideal, then we say it is a Prime Ideal.

(1) This notion does not generalize to noncommutative rings. If we tried "naively" looking for ideals of \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{2}(\mathbb {C}) which are prime, then we will not find any. It remains an open problem how to define prime ideals for noncommutative rings.

(2) Hungerford Algebra Exercise 9(b) in Section III.2 asks the reader to prove: if D is a division ring and R=\mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(D), then R has zero divisors and so the trivial ideal (0) is prime, which means R\cong R/(0) but R is not an integral domain. This is because R is not a commutative ring. (See? Things get really weird when trying to think about prime ideals in a noncommutative ring.)

fr:title.text: Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.4.13

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let P\mathrel {\triangleleft } R be an ideal. Then P is Prime Ideal if and only if the Quotient Ring R/P is a Integral domain.

fr:title.text: Maximal ideals of a commutative ring are prime

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Maximal ideals of a commutative ring are prime

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring. If M\mathrel {\triangleleft } R is a Maximal ideal, then M is prime.
Assume M is maximal. Then R/M is a field (since Ideal is maximal iff quotient ring is field). Then R/M is a Field. Then M is prime by Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of Maximal Ideals
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Krull's Idealtheorie in Ringen ohne Endlichkeitsbedingung (1929)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R\neq 0 be a nonzero unital Ring. Then there exists a maximal ideal M\mathrel {\triangleleft } R of R.

The typical proof offered is: consider the lattice of proper ideals of R ordered by inclusion. There exists at least one ideal of R (e.g., the Trivial ideal). Then Zorn's lemma implies there exists a maximal element of a chain containing the trivial ideal.
(1) This is often called "Krull's theorem", which is unfortunate because there are about a half dozen different results in ring theory called "Krull's theorem".

(2) The condition that R is unital is really critical. For example, we can turn any additive group G into a nonunital ring by defining multiplication x\star y=0 for all x,y\in R. There is no maximal ideal for such a ring

(3) In ZF set theory, this theorem implies the axiom of choice. Hodges first proved it. For a review of this, see Alexei Entin's "Maximal Ideals in Commutative Rings and the Axiom of Choice" (arXiv:2404.18351).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal generated by a set
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a unital Ring with 1\neq 0. Let A\subseteq R be any subset of R. Then the Ideal Generated by A is the ideal \langle A\rangle of R equal to \langle A\rangle = \bigcap _{A\subseteq I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R}I. This is the smallest ideal of R containing A.
When A=\{a_{1},…,a_{n}\} is a finite set, then we just write \langle a_{1},…,a_{n}\rangle or (a_{1},…,a_{n}) for the ideal generated by A.
Exercise: What is \langle \emptyset \rangle the ideal generated by the empty set?
Exercise: If we allow R to be a nonunital ring, then is the ideal generated by a set still well-defined?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fields only have trivial ideals
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.4.9(2)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring. Then R is a Field if and only if its only ideals are 0 and R.
We see R is a field iff every nonzero element is a unit (by definition of a field).
(\Longrightarrow ) If R is a field, then every nonzero ideal contains a unit, which means that R is the only nonzero ideal.

(\Longleftarrow ) Suppose the only ideals of R is the trivial ideal and R itself. Let u be any nonzero element of R. Then (u)=R so 1\in (u). Hence there must be some v\in R such that 1=vu (i.e., u is a unit). Therefore every nonzero element of R is a unit, hence R must be a field.

fr:title.text: Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Corollary 7.4.10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then any nonzero Ring morphism from \mathbb {F} into another ring must be an Injective function.
The Kernel of a ring morphism is an ideal. The kernel of a nonzero morphism is a proper ideal, hence must be 0 by Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Principal Ideal Domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An Integral domain R is called a Principal Ideal Domain if every ideal is principal (i.e., generated by a single element).

Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain. Let I_{1},I_{2},…,I_{n},I_{n+1},…,\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be ideals of R such that I_{1}\subseteq I_{2}\subseteq …\subseteq I_{n}\subseteq I_{n+1}\subseteq …. Then there exists an n_{0}\in \mathbb {N} such that I_{n}=I_{n_{0}} for all n\geq n_{0}.
Let I=\bigcup _{n}I_{n}. If a,b\in I, then a\in I_{m} and b\in I_{n} for some m,n\in \mathbb {N}. If p=\max (m,n) and a,b\in I_{p}, then a\pm b\in I_{p}\subseteq I. So I forms a group under addition.
For any a\in I, there is an n\in \mathbb {N} such that a\in I_{n}. Then for any r\in R we have ra\in I_{n}\subseteq I. So I forms an ideal.

Since R is a Principal Ideal Domain, there exists an a_{0} such that I=(a_{0}). But then there exists an n_{0} such that a\in I_{n_{0}}. So I=(a_{0})\subseteq I_{n_{0}}. Then for any n\geq n_{0}, we have I\subseteq I_{n_{0}}\subseteq I_{n}\subseteq I which proves the chain of ideals stabilizes.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Euclidean Domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 8.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An Integral domain R is said to be a Euclidean Domain if there is a norm N\colon R\to \mathbb {N}_{0} such that for any two elements a,b\in R with b\neq 0, there exists elements [the quotient] q\in R and [the remainder] r\in R such that a=qb+r and r=0\quad \hbox {or}\quad N(r)<N(b).
The integers form a Euclidean Domain when given the absolute value as its norm N(x)=|x|. This is because of the Division algorithm.

fr:title.text: Euclidean Domains are Principal Ideal Domains

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Euclidean Domains are Principal Ideal Domains
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 8.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every ideal in a Euclidean Domain is principal: if R is any Euclidean domain and I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R with 0\neq I, then I=(d) where d is any nonzero element of I of minimum norm.

Let R be a Commutative Ring. Let a,b\in R with b\neq 0. We say a is a Multiple of b if there exists some x\in R such that a=bx. In this case, we say b divides a (or b is a divisor of a) and we write b\mathrel {\bigm |} a.

Let R be a Commutative Ring. Let a,b\in R with b\neq 0. A Greatest Common Divisor of a and b is a nonzero element d\in R such that:
It's a common divisor: d\mathrel {\bigm |} a and d\mathrel {\bigm |} b, and
It's greatest: for any d'\in R such that d'\mathrel {\bigm |} a and d'\mathrel {\bigm |} b, we have d'\mathrel {\bigm |} d. A greatest common divisor of a and b is denoted by \gcd (a,b) or (abusing notation) by (a,b).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This isn't necessarily unique, we may have multiple distinct greatest common divisors of a and b. When it is unique, we call the ring a GCD Domain (and it turns out to be an Integral domain).

fr:title.text: Existence and Uniqueness of GCD in Euclidean Domains

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence and Uniqueness of GCD in Euclidean Domains

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Euclidean Domain. Then for any nonzero a,b\in R,
There exists a unique d\in R (up to unit multiple) such that d=\gcd (a,b); and
there exists x,y\in R such that \gcd (a,b)=ax+by.

This follows by performing Euclid's algorithm; i.e., we repeatedly apply the division algorithm to find b=q_{1}a+r_{1}, a=q_{2}r_{1}+r_{2}, r_{1}=q_{3}r_{2}+r_{3}, …, r_{n+1}=q_{n+3}r_{n+2}. Then r_{n+2}=\gcd (a,b) since:
(1) (r_{n+2})\subseteq (a,b)
(2) (a,b)\subseteq (r_{n+2})
Hence by (1) and (2) and since Euclidean Domains are Principal Ideal Domains, we have (r_{n+2})=(a,b) which implies the result.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Prime element
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML ring_2:def 8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let p\in R be a nonzero element which is not a unit. We say p is Prime if whenever p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab then either p\mathrel {\bigm |} a or p\mathrel {\bigm |} b.
Exercise: Can this be generalized to a unital associative ring?

fr:title.text: Element is prime iff it generates a nonzero prime ideal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Element is prime iff it generates a nonzero prime ideal
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML ring_2:24

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring where 1\neq 0, let p\in R. Then p is a Prime element if and only if (p) is a nonzero Prime Ideal.

(\Longrightarrow ) Let p be a Prime element. Then for any a,b\in R, \begin {align*}ab\in (p) &\iff \exists r\in R\ldotp ab=pr\\ &\iff p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab \hbox { iff }p\mathrel {\bigm |} a\hbox { or }p\mathrel {\bigm |} b\\ &\iff a\in (p)\hbox { or }b\in (p)\\ &\iff (p) \hbox { is a prime ideal}\end {align*}

(\Longleftarrow ) Let P=(p) be a nonzero prime ideal. For any a,b\in R, if p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab, then ab\in P, which implies a\in P or b\in P by definition of prime ideals. So we have p\mathrel {\bigm |} a or p\mathrel {\bigm |} b. Hence p is a prime element of R.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Irreducible element
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML ring_2:def 9

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let p\in R be a nonzero element which is not a unit. We say p is Irreducible if whenever d\mathrel {\bigm |} p, then we have either d=pu or d=u for some unit u\in R.
When p is not irreducible, we say it is Reducible.
Exercise: Can this be generalized to a unital associative ring?

Let R be a Commutative Ring, let p\in R be an element of R. Then p is irreducible if and only if its Principal Ideal (p) is a nonzero Maximal ideal among principal ideals (i.e., (p) may be a proper subideal of some ideal I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R where I may or may not be a proper ideal, just so long as I is not a principal ideal).
If a=pu, then (a)=(p), hence (p) is maximal among proper principal ideals.

(\Longleftarrow ) Suppose (p) is maximal among principal proper ideals. We want to show p is irreducible. Suppose there exists some a\in R such that a\mathrel {\bigm |} p, which is equivalent to saying (a)\subseteq (p). Then either (a)=R (which means a\in R^{\times } is a unit) or (a)=(p) (which implies a=pu for some unit u\in R^{\times }). In both cases, we have p is irreducible.

fr:title.text: Irreducible elements are prime in a PID

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Irreducible elements are prime in a PID

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be Principal Ideal Domain, let p\in R be an element of R. If p is irreducible, then p is prime.
Assume p is irreducible. Then we proved this is equivalent to (p) is maximal among principal ideals. Then (p) is prime, which implies p is prime.

fr:title.text: Nonzero prime elements of an integral domain are irreducible

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Nonzero prime elements of an integral domain are irreducible

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be an Integral domain, let p\in R be a nonzero element p\neq 0. If p is a prime element of R, then p is irreducible.

Let p\in R^{*} be a nonzero element. Assume p is prime. Then for any a,d\in R such that p\mathrel {\bigm |} ad we have \hbox {either }p\mathrel {\bigm |} a\hbox { or }p\mathrel {\bigm |} d, by definition of prime.
Now, by definition of irreducible, suppose we had some d\in R d\mathrel {\bigm |} p. We will show that either d=pu or d=u for some unit u\in R.

Since d\mathrel {\bigm |} p, this means there exists an a\in R such that p=ad. Since p is prime and p\mathrel {\bigm |} p (i.e., p\mathrel {\bigm |} ad), this means p\mathrel {\bigm |} a or p\mathrel {\bigm |} d. Then we argue by cases.

Case 1: p\mathrel {\bigm |} a. Then there exists a b\in R such that a=pb. But then p=ad=(pb)d, using distributivity and subtraction gives us (1-bd)p=0. Then bd=1 since p\neq 0. Then d is a unit, since R is an integral domain. Then p is irreducible by definition.
Case 2: p\mathrel {\bigm |} d. The argument is similar to case 1.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Associated Irreducibles
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML gcd_1:def 3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be Commutative Ring, let p\in R and q\in R be irreducible elements of R. We say p and q are associates (or p is associated to q) if there exists some unit u\in R^{\times } such that p=uq. This is a predicate, so it's well-defined.
This is a symmetric predicate since u^{-1}\in R^{\times } so we have u^{-1}p=q, too.
It's not too hard to see it's really an Equivalence relation.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Unique Factorization Domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML ring_2:def 15
Hungerford Algebra Definition III.3.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Some examples we have seen before:

fr:ol.fr:li: The integers \mathbb {Z} form a unique factorization domain.
The Gaussian integers \mathbb {Z}[i]\subseteq \mathbb {C} form a unique factorization domain.

The integers \mathbb {Z}[\sqrt {-5}] adjoined with \sqrt {-5} is not a unique factorization domain, since 6=2\dot 3=(1+\sqrt {-5})(1-\sqrt {-5}) are two possible factorizations. Hell, \mathbb {Z}[\sqrt {-5}] isn't even a Principal Ideal Domain.

fr:title.text: In a UFD, elements are irreducible iff prime

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: In a UFD, elements are irreducible iff prime
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 8.3.12

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Unique Factorization Domain, let p\in R be an element of R. Then p is prime if and only if p is irreducible.
(\Longrightarrow ) Well, since a UFD is an integral domain, this follows immediately from Nonzero prime elements of an integral domain are irreducible.
(\Longleftarrow ) Assume p is irreducible. We want to prove p is prime.

Let a,b\in R be arbitrary. Assume p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab. Then there exists some c\in R such that ab=pc. We can write the unique factorization of a as a=u\prod ^{N}_{i=1}p_{i}^{n_{i}} and the unique factorization of b as b=v\prod ^{M}_{j=1}q_{j}^{m_{j}} and the unique factorization of c as c=w\prod ^{L}_{k=1}r_{k}^{\ell _{k}}. Then p must associate with one of the irreducibles appearing in the factorization of a or {b}. We have ab=pc be uv\prod ^{N}_{i=1}p_{i}^{n_{i}}\prod ^{M}_{j=1}q_{j}^{m_{j}}=wp\prod ^{L}_{k=1}r_{k}^{\ell _{k}}, and by uniqueness of the factorizations N+M-1=L, and either p_{i}=pu'\quad \hbox {for some }i\hbox { and }u'\in R^{\times } (which means p\mathrel {\bigm |} a), or q_{j}=pu'\quad \hbox {for some }j\hbox { and }u'\in R^{\times } (which means p\mathrel {\bigm |} b). Hence p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab implies p\mathrel {\bigm |} a or p\mathrel {\bigm |} b, which implies p is a prime element of R.

fr:title.text: Uniqueness of GCD in a UFD

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Uniqueness of GCD in a UFD

fr:title.text: Principal ideal domains are unique factorization domains

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Principal ideal domains are unique factorization domains
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 8.3.14

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let a\in R be a nonzero non-invertible element of R. Then there exists irreducible elements p_{1},…,p_{n}\in R such that a=p_{1}(…)p_{n}. Further, if q_{1},…,q_{m}\in R are irreducible and such that a=q_{1}(…)q_{m} then m=n and for each i=1,…,n we have q_{i}=u_{i}p_{i} where u\in R^{\times } is a unit.
In other words, R is a Unique Factorization Domain.
There are two claims: (1) there is a factorization, and (2) the factorization is unique.
Claim 1: Existence of a factorization. Assume for contradiction a\in R does not have a factorization. Then ua\in R does not have a factorization for any unit u\in R^{\times }.
We setup a set S:=\{(r)\mathrel {\triangleleft } R\mid r\hbox { does not have a factorization into irreducibles}\}. Assume for contradiction that S\neq \emptyset .

Let (a) be a maximal element of S by Zorn's lemma. We have a is not irreducible, so by definition we can write it as a=xy where x,y\notin R^{\times } are not units, so (a)\subset (x) and (a)\subset (y) are proper subsets.

But since (a) is a maximal element of a chain, (x)
otin S and (y)
otin S, so x and y have a factorization. This gives us a contradiction, which means our assumption S
eq \emptyset is wrong. We conclude S=\emptyset . Hence we've proven the factorization of elements exists.

Claim 2: Uniqueness of factorization. This may be proven in many, many ways. Assume for contradiction this is not true, so we may factorize \prod ^{n}_{i}p_{i}=\prod ^{m}_{j}q_{j}, where n is minimal (i.e., the factorization \prod ^{n}_{i}p_{i} is the smallest possible factorization with fewest possible factors).

We have n\geq 1, p=p_{1} divides p\mathrel {\bigm |}\prod q_{j}. Then there exists a j_{0} such that p\mathrel {\bigm |} q_{j_{0}} since p_{i} and q_{j} are all prime and irreducible. Then p=uq_{j_{0}} for some unit u\in R^{\times } (since p and q_{j_{0}} are irreducible). Then p_{1}\prod ^{n}_{i=2}p_{i}=(uq_{j_{0}})u^{-1}\prod ^{m}_{j\neq j_{0}}q_{j} which implies \prod ^{n}_{i=2}p_{i}=u^{-1}\prod ^{m}_{j\neq j_{0}}q_{j}. This contradicts the assumption that \prod ^{n}_{i=1}p_{i} is the minimal factorization.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Corollary 8.3.15

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The integers are a unique factorization domain.

Consider the mapping \mathbb {Z} / mn\mathbb {Z}\to \mathbb {Z} / m\mathbb {Z}\times \mathbb {Z} / n\mathbb {Z} given by x\mapsto (x\bmod {m},x\bmod {n}) is an isomorphism of additive groups. Surjectivity means a solution exists, injectivity means the solution is unique.

fr:title.text: Generalizing Chinese Remainder theorem to rings

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Generalizing Chinese Remainder theorem to rings

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We want to generalize the Chinese Remainder Theorem from integers to arbitrary Rings.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Comaximal ideals
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a unital Commutative Ring. Let A\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R and B\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be ideals of R. We say A and B are Comaximal if their sum is the entire ring A+B=R.
We see that this is a symmetric predicate in A and B since A+B=B+A.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Abstract Chinese Remainder Theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 7.6.17
Hungerford Algebra Theorem III.2.25

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Ring. Let I and J be comaximal two-sided ideals of R. Then
the map R/(I\cap J)\to (R/I)\times (R/J) defined by sending x\mapsto (x+I,x+J) is a Ring Isomorphism; and
furthermore if we write I\cdot J=\langle \{ab\in R\mid a\in I,b\in J\}\rangle for the two-sided ideal generated by products of elements of I and J, then I\cdot J=I\cap J.

(1) Let \varphi \colon R\to (R/I)\times (R/J) be the mapping such that \varphi (x)=(x+I,x+J) for any x\in R. Its kernel is I\cap J. Then by the first isomorphism theorem \varphi '\colon R/(I\cap J)\to (R/I)\times (R/J) is injective because it has a trivial kernel. We need to show it is surjective.

(2) Since I and J are comaximal, there exists a\in I and b\in J such that a+b=1. We want to show I\cap J\subseteq I\cdot J. Let x\in I\cap J. Then x=x\cdot 1=xa+xb, so xa\in JI and xb\in IJ, hence x\in I\cdot J.
We see I\cap J\supseteq I\cdot J obviously.

We can "define" the rational numbers \mathbb {Q} from the integers \mathbb {Z} intuitively as \mathbb {Q}=\{\frac {a}{b}\mid a,b\in \mathbb {Z},b\neq 0\}, but \frac {a}{b}=\frac {c}{d}\iff ad=bc. Furthermore, the operations on \mathbb {Q} are defined using the operations from \mathbb {Z} as \frac {a}{b}+\frac {c}{d}=\frac {ad+bc}{bd} and \frac {a}{b}\cdot \frac {c}{d}=\frac {ac}{bd}. This construction generalizes to any Integral domain.

Note: \mathbb {Q} is the "smallest" field containing \mathbb {Z} in the sense that if \varphi \colon \mathbb {Z}\hookrightarrow \mathbb {F} is an injection into a field, then there exists an extension \overline {\varphi }\colon \mathbb {Q}\hookrightarrow \mathbb {F} such that \overline {\varphi }(m)=\varphi (m) for all m\in \mathbb {Z}.

fr:title.text: Universal property of field of fractions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Universal property of field of fractions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be any Integral domain. Then there exists a unique Field \mathbb {F} (unique up to isomorphism) and an injection i\colon R\hookrightarrow \mathbb {F} such that for all other fields \Bbbk if \varphi \colon R\hookrightarrow \Bbbk , then there exists an extension \overline {\varphi }\colon \mathbb {F}\hookrightarrow \Bbbk such that the following diagram commutes:
We call \mathbb {F} the Ring of Fractions of R.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This can be generalized to any commutative ring; Matsumara calls it the "total quotient ring" (or the "total ring of fractions").

fr:ol.fr:li: When applied to R=\mathbb {Z}, we obtain \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {Q}.
When applied to any field R=\Bbbk , we obtained \mathbb {F}=\Bbbk the field is its own field of fractions.
When applied to the polynomial ring R=\mathbb {Q}[x], we obtain \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {Q}(x) the ring of rational polynomials.
If \mathbb {F} is the field of fractions of R, then \mathbb {F}(x) is the field of fractions for R[x].

If R=\mathbb {Q}[{[x]}] is the ring of formal power series, then its field of fractions is \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {Q}(\mkern -3mu(x)\mkern -3mu) the ring of formal Laurent series \sum ^{\infty }_{k=-n}a_{k}x^{k}.

fr:title.text: Ring of polynomials is a UFD iff ring of coefficients is a UFD

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring of polynomials is a UFD iff ring of coefficients is a UFD

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a ring. Then R is a Unique Factorization Domain if and only if R[x] is a Unique Factorization Domain.

fr:title.text: Properties of ring of polynomials over UFDs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of ring of polynomials over UFDs

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Unique Factorization Domain. Let \mathbb {F}=\mathop {\textrm {Frac}}\nolimits (R) be the field of fractions of R. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: R[x] is a Unique Factorization Domain.
If p\in R^{*} is irreducible, then p\in R[x] is irreducible.
If f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] is primitive and irredubile, then f(x)\in R[x] is irreducible and these are all the irreducible elements of R[x].

fr:title.text: Primitive Polynomial and Content of Polynomial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Primitive Polynomial and Content of Polynomial

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Unique Factorization Domain, let x be a formal variable. Let f(x)\in R[x] be a nonconstant polynomial. Then we define the Content of f to be the c(f)\in R^{*} equal to the greatest common divisor of its nonzero coefficients, and the Primitive Part of f to be the polynomial f_{0}\in R[x] such that c(f_{0})=1 and f(x)=c(f)f_{0}(x). We say f is Primitive if f=f_{0}.

fr:title.text: Factorization of formal polynomials with coefficients in UFDs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Factorization of formal polynomials with coefficients in UFDs
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 9.3.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Unique Factorization Domain, let \mathbb {F}=\mathop {\textrm {Frac}}\nolimits (R) be its field of fractions, let x be a formal variable. Let p(x)\in R[x].

If p(x) is reducible in \mathbb {F}[x], then p(x) is reducible in R[x]. More precisely: if p(x)=A(x)B(x) for some nonconstant polynomials A(x),B(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x], then there are nonzero elements r,s\in \mathbb {F} such that rA(x)=a(x) and sB(x)=b(x) both lie in R[x] and p(x)=a(x)b(x) is a factorization in R[x].

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is called "Gauss's Lemma", but as far as I can tell, like most things named after Gauss, it's completely unmerited.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eisenstein criteria of reducibility
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 9.4.13

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be an Integral domain, let x be a formal variable. Let f(x)\in R[x] be a (nonconstant) monic polynomial f(x)=x^{n}+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+…+a_{1}x+a_{0}. Let P\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be a prime ideal of R. Suppose for all j=1,…,n we have p_{j}\in R and a_{0}\notin P^{2}. Then f(x) is irreducible.

Since P is a prime ideal, R/P is an integral domain (by Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain). Then both \overline {a(x)} and \overline {b(x)} have 0 constant terms, i.e., the constant terms of both a(x) and b(x) belong to P.
But then the constant term a_{0} of f(x) may be written as the product of these two, which contradicts the hypothesis that a_{0}\notin P^{2}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Field is traditionally defined as a set F with two binary operators, addition (denoted +) and multiplication (denoted \cdot ), satisfying the field axioms:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity of addition: for all x,y,z\in F, (x+y)+z=x+(y+z)
Commutativity of addition: for all x,y\in F, x+y=y+x
Additive identity: there exists a 0\in F such that for all x\in F we have 0+x=x and x+0=x
Additive inverses: for each x\in F there is a unique y\in F such that x+y=0 and y+x=0; in this case, we usually denote y as (-x)
Associativity of multiplication: for all x,y,z\in F, (x\cdot y)\cdot z=x\cdot (y\cdot z)
Commutativity of multiplication: for all x,y\in F, x\cdot y=y\cdot x
Multiplicative identity: there exists a 1\in F such that for all x\in F we have 1\cdot x=x and x\cdot 1=x
Multiplicative inverses: for each x\in F which is nonzero x\neq 0 there is a unique y\in F such that x\cdot y=1 and y\cdot x=1; usually we denote y as x^{-1}
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: for all x,y,z\in F, we have x\cdot (y+z)=(x\cdot y)+(x\cdot z) and (x+y)\cdot z=(x\cdot z)+(x\cdot y)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that some of these are redundant.
Also note: fields are usually written in blackboard bold, and the generic field is either \mathbb {F} or \Bbbk (since the German word for field is "Körper").

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector Space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.20
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. A Vector Space over \mathbb {F} consists of a set V equipped with vector addition +\colon V\times V\to V and scalar multiplication \cdot \colon \mathbb {F}\times V\to V such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: for all u,v\in V, we have u+v=v+u
Associativity: for all u,v,w\in V, we have (u+v)+w=u+(v+w)
Additive identity: there exists a \vec {0}\in V such that for all v\in V we have v+\vec {0}=v
Additive inverse: for each v\in V there exists a w\in V such that v+w=\vec {0}
Associativity of scalar multiplication: for all v\in V and a,b\in \mathbb {F}, we have (ab)v=a(bv)
Multiplicative identity: The multiplicative unital element 1\in \mathbb {F} is such that for all v\in V we have 1v=v
Distributivity: for all a,b\in \mathbb {F} and u,v\in V we have a(u+v)=au+av and (a+b)v=av+bv

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Compare this to the definition of a Real vector space from elementary linear algebra. When \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {R}, we call V a real vector space. When \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {C}, we call V a Complex Vector Space.

fr:title.text: Finite tuples over a field form a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite tuples over a field form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider \mathbb {F}^{n} the set of all n-tuples with values in \mathbb {F}. This is a vector space with addition and multiplication defined by (u_{1},…,u_{n})+(v_{1},…,v_{n})=(u_{1}+v_{1},…,u_{n}+v_{n}) a(u_{1},…,u_{n})=(au_{1},…,au_{n}) Then this really is a vector space.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector space of sequences
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Example 1.23
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Then \mathbb {F}^{\infty } is the set of all sequences over \mathbb {F}. Then vector addition defined componentwise (u_{k})+(v_{k})=(u_{k}+v_{k}) and scalar multiplication defined componentwise a(u_{n})=(au_{n}) give us a vector space.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Polynomials form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Example 1.23
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F}[z] be the set of all polynomial with coefficients in \mathbb {F} and in unknown z. Then defining (p+q)(z)=p(z)+q(z) and (ap)(z)=ap(z) for any a\in \mathbb {F} and p,q\in \mathbb {F}[z] forms vector addition and scalar multiplication.

fr:title.text: Field-valued functions form a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field-valued functions form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Example 1.25
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let D\neq \emptyset be any set. Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Then the Set of all functions \mathbb {F}^{D} forms a vector space. Vector addition of f,g\in \mathbb {F}^{D} is given by (f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x) for any x\in D, and scalar multiplication is given by (af)(x)=af(x) for any a\in \mathbb {F}.

There are various related vector spaces of interest to Mathematicians. For example, when \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {R} and D\subseteq \mathbb {R}, the set of all continuous real-valued functions on D forms a subspace of \mathbb {R}^{D}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Zero vector is unique
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.26
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Then the additive identity \vec {0}\in V is unique.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Additive inverse is unique
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.27
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. For each v\in V, there is a unique additive inverse of v in V.
Suppose w and w' are additive inverses of v. Then w=w+0=w+(v+w')=(w+v)+w'=0+w'=w' which gives us w=w' as desired.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Additive inverse and vector subtraction
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Notation 1.28

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. We denote by -v the additive inverse of v\in V.
Similarly, for any v,w\in V, we denote by v-w the expression v+(-w).

fr:title.text: Scalar multiplication by zero gives zero vector

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Scalar multiplication by zero gives zero vector
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.30
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v\in V and 0_{F}\in \mathbb {F}. Then 0_{F}v=\vec {0}.
We see by distributivity, 0_{F}v=(0_{F}+0_{F})v=0_{F}v+0_{F}v, and then subtracting 0_{F}v from both sides yields \vec {0}=0_{F}v-0_{F}v=(0_{F}v+0_{F}v)-0_{F}v=0_{F}v as desired.

fr:title.text: Scalar multiples of zero vector are the zero vector

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Scalar multiples of zero vector are the zero vector
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.31
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let \vec {0}\in V and a\in \mathbb {F}. Then a\vec {0}=\vec {0}.
We see a\vec {0}=a(\vec {0}+\vec {0})=a\vec {0}+a\vec {0}, then adding the additive inverse of a\vec {0} to both sides yields the result.

fr:title.text: Negating a vector by multiplying by minus one

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Negating a vector by multiplying by minus one
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.32
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v\in V. Then (-1)v=-v.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.33
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.3.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let U\subseteq V be a subset. Then we call U a Subspace of V if U is a vector space over \mathbb {F} under the same operations that make V a vector space over \mathbb {F}.
In particular, V is always a subspace of itself.
Compare this to Subspace of a real vector space from elementary linear algebra.

fr:title.text: Criteria for subset to be a subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for subset to be a subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.34
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 4.3.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let U\subseteq V be a subset. Then U is a subspace of V if the following conditions all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Additive identity: \vec {0}\in U
Closed under addition: for any u,v\in U, u+v\in U
Closed under scalar multiplication: for any a\in \mathbb {F} and u\in U, we have au\in U

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Trivial subspaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.3.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Then V is a subspace of V and also \{\vec {0}\} is a subspace of V. They are called the Trivial Subspaces of V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sum of subspaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.36
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.4.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V be subspaces of V. We define the (Subspace) Sum of U_{1} and U_{2} to be the set U_{1}+U_{2}=\{u_{1}+u_{2}\mid u_{1}\in U_{1},u_{2}\in U_{2}\}.
More precisely, this is a subspace of V.
This can be extended to any finite number of subspaces of V.

fr:title.text: Sum of subspaces is smallest subspace containing the summands

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sum of subspaces is smallest subspace containing the summands
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.40

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},…,U_{m}\subseteq V be subspaces of a vector space V. Then U_{1}+…+U_{m} is the smallest subspace of V containing U_{1}, …, U_{n}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum of spaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.36
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.4.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V be subspaces of a vector space. We call U_{1}+U_{2} the Direct Sum if each element of U_{1}+U_{2} can be written in only one way as a sum u_{1}+u_{2} where u_{1}\in U_{1} and u_{2}\in U_{2}.
In this case, we write U_{1}\oplus U_{2}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criterion for direct sum
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.45
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.4.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V. Then U_{1}+U_{2} is a direct sum if and only if the only way we can write \vec {0}=u_{1}+u_{2} with u_{1}\in U_{1} and u_{2}\in U_{2} is for u_{1}=u_{2}=\vec {0}.

fr:title.text: Direct sum of two subspaces intersect in the zero subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum of two subspaces intersect in the zero subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.46
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.4.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V be subspaces. Then U_{1}+U_{2} is a direct sum if and only if U_{1}\cap U_{2}=\{\vec {0}\}.

fr:title.text: Direct sum as Cartesian product of underlying sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum as Cartesian product of underlying sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If we are just given any two vector spaces V_{1} and V_{2} over the same field \mathbb {F}, then we can still form the direct sum of these spaces. We just take V_{1}\oplus V_{2}=\{(v_{1},v_{2})\mid v_{1}\in V_{1},v_{2}\in V_{2}\} and the operations are defined componentwise.
This is known as the External Direct Sum, but it is not taught usually to undergraduates.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Field is traditionally defined as a set F with two binary operators, addition (denoted +) and multiplication (denoted \cdot ), satisfying the field axioms:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity of addition: for all x,y,z\in F, (x+y)+z=x+(y+z)
Commutativity of addition: for all x,y\in F, x+y=y+x
Additive identity: there exists a 0\in F such that for all x\in F we have 0+x=x and x+0=x
Additive inverses: for each x\in F there is a unique y\in F such that x+y=0 and y+x=0; in this case, we usually denote y as (-x)
Associativity of multiplication: for all x,y,z\in F, (x\cdot y)\cdot z=x\cdot (y\cdot z)
Commutativity of multiplication: for all x,y\in F, x\cdot y=y\cdot x
Multiplicative identity: there exists a 1\in F such that for all x\in F we have 1\cdot x=x and x\cdot 1=x
Multiplicative inverses: for each x\in F which is nonzero x\neq 0 there is a unique y\in F such that x\cdot y=1 and y\cdot x=1; usually we denote y as x^{-1}
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: for all x,y,z\in F, we have x\cdot (y+z)=(x\cdot y)+(x\cdot z) and (x+y)\cdot z=(x\cdot z)+(x\cdot y)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that some of these are redundant.
Also note: fields are usually written in blackboard bold, and the generic field is either \mathbb {F} or \Bbbk (since the German word for field is "Körper").
A Real Vector Space consists of a set V with two binary operators, scalar multiplication \odot \colon \mathbb {R}\times V\to V and vector addition \oplus \colon V\times V\to V, such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Closure of \oplus : for any u,v\in V, we have u\oplus v\in V;
Commutativity of \oplus : for any u,v\in V, we have u\oplus v=v\oplus u;
Associativity of \oplus : for any u,v,w\in V, we have (u\oplus v)\oplus w=u\oplus (v\oplus W);
Unit of \oplus : there exists a \vec {0}\in V such that for all u\in V we have \vec {0}+u=u and also u+\vec {0}=u;
Existence of negation: for each u\in V, there exists a -u\in V such that u\oplus -u=\vec {0};
Closure of \odot : for any real number c\in \mathbb {R} and for any u\in V, we have c\odot u\in V;
Left distributivity of \odot over \oplus : for any c\in \mathbb {R} and u,v\in V, we have c\odot (u\oplus v)=(c\odot u)\oplus (c\odot v);
Right distributivity of \odot over \oplus : for any c,d\in \mathbb {R} and u,v\in V, we have (c+d)\odot u=(c\odot u)\oplus (d\odot u);
Unit of \odot : for any u\in V, 1\odot u=u

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We call elements of V Vectors of V.

Notation varies book to book, especially with introductory linear algebra. Later on in Mathematics (and physics) we just write u+v for vector addition and c\cdot u or cu for scalar multiplication. But since we are trying to be explicit and clear, we demarcate vector addition and scalar multiplication with separate notation from field operations.
We could replace the real numbers \mathbb {R} with the complex numbers \mathbb {C} to define a notion of a complex vector space, nothing changes except where the scalars live.

Let \mathrm {Mat}(m,n,\mathbb {R}) be the set of all m\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {R}. If we equip \mathrm {Mat}(m,n,\mathbb {R}) with matrix addition as its vector addition, and use its usual Scalar multiplication (on a matrix), then we have a real vector space.

fr:title.text: Tuples of real numbers form a real vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Tuples of real numbers form a real vector space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n be a real number. Let us denote by \mathbb {R}^{n} the set of all n-tuples of real numbers (x_{1},…,x_{n}). If we define (x_{1},…,x_{n})\oplus (y_{1},…,y_{n})=(x_{1}+y_{1},…,x_{n}+y_{n}) and similarly c\odot (x_{1},…,x_{n})=(cx_{1},…,cx_{n}). Then we have a real vector space.

fr:title.text: Polynomials form a real vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Polynomials form a real vector space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let us write down the set of all polynomials in one unknown x with real coefficients as \mathbb {R}[x]. When equipped with polynomial addition as vector addition, and scalar multiplication just multiplies each coefficient "in the obvious way", then this forms a real vector space.

fr:title.text: Vector spaces don't always have a dot product

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector spaces don't always have a dot product

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Not all vector spaces have a well-defined "dot product". The only one which has an obvious dot product is the vector space of n-tuples \mathbb {R}^{n}, where we define:
We will just take for granted this is a well-defined notion for \mathbb {R}^{n}.

fr:title.text: Subspace of a real vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subspace of a real vector space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a real vector space with vector addition \oplus and scalar multiplication \odot . Let U\subseteq V be a subset of vectors. We call U a Subspace of V if it forms a vector space using \oplus restricted to U, and scalar multiplication restricted to U.
This means the zero vector \vec {0}\in V must be an element of U.

fr:title.text: Criteria for a subset being a subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for a subset being a subspace

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a real vector space with vector addition \oplus and scalar multiplication \odot . Then a subset U\subseteq V forms a subspace of V provided:

fr:ol.fr:li: for any u,v\in U, we have u\oplus v\in U; and
for any c\in \mathbb {R} and u\in U, we have c\odot u\in U.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a real vector space. Then the Trivial Subspace of V consists of just the zero vector.

fr:title.text: Subspace iff closed under arbitrary linear combinations

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subspace iff closed under arbitrary linear combinations

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a real vector space, let U\subseteq V. Then U is a subspace of V if and only if for every u_{1},u_{2}\in U and c_{1},c_{2}\in \mathbb {R} we have (c_{1}\odot u_{1})\oplus (c_{2}\odot u_{2})\in U.

fr:title.text: Matrices are a subspace of tuples

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrices are a subspace of tuples

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We claim that the vector space of m\times n matrices \mathrm {Mat}(m,n,\mathbb {R}) is a subspace of mn-tuples \mathbb {R}^{m\times n}.
Let v_{1},…,v_{k}\in V be vectors. We call a vector u\in V a Linear Combination of v_{1}, …, v_{k} if there exists c_{1},…,c_{k}\in \mathbb {R} such that

fr:title.text: Span of a set of vectors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Span of a set of vectors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a real vector space, let S\subseteq V be a (possibly infinite) set of vectors. We define the Span of S to be the set of finite linear combinations of elements of S:
Furthermore, if W\subseteq V is a subspace of V such that \mathrm {span}(S)=W, then we call S a Spanning Set of W.
Let V be a real vector space, let S\subseteq V be a subset. Then \mathrm {span}(S) is a subspace of V.

fr:title.text: Matrices are a subspace of tuples

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrices are a subspace of tuples

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We claim that the vector space of m\times n matrices \mathrm {Mat}(m,n,\mathbb {R}) is a subspace of mn-tuples \mathbb {R}^{m\times n}.
Let V be a real vector space, let v_{1},…,v_{n}\in V. We say these vectors are Linearly dependent if there are coefficients c_{1},…,c_{n}\in \mathbb {R} such that:
If there are no such coefficients, then we say v_{1}, …, v_{n} are Linearly Independent.

A set of nonzero vectors \{v_{1},…,v_{n}\} of a real vector space V is linearly independent if and only if at least one of the vectors v_{k} is expressible as a linear combination of the other vectors:
where not all coefficients c_{j}\in \mathbb {R} are zero.

fr:title.text: Determinant is nonzero iff its columns are linearly independent

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Determinant is nonzero iff its columns are linearly independent

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbf {M} be an n\times n matrix written as a list of n column vectors: \mathbf {M}=(v_{1}\mid …\mid v_{n}) Then \det (\mathbf {M})\neq 0 if and only if the columns v_{1}, …, v_{n} are linearly independent.
Let V be a real vector space, let B\subseteq V be a subset of V. If \mathrm {span}(B)=V and there is no proper subset A\subset B such that \mathrm {span}(A)=V, then we call B a Basis of V.

Let e_{j}\in \mathbb {R}^{n} have 1 in its j^{\text {th}} component and 0 in all other components. Then \{e_{1},…,e_{n}\} forms a basis of \mathbb {R}^{n} is called the Canonical Basis of \mathbb {R}^{n}.

fr:title.text: Any two bases have the same number of elements

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Any two bases have the same number of elements

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space, let B be a basis for V. If B has finitely many elements, then any other basis of V has the same number of elements as B.
Let V be a real vector space.
If there is a finite basis B for V, then we define the Dimension of V to be the number \dim (V) of elements of B.
Otherwise, we define the dimension of V to be \dim (V)=\infty .
When \dim (V)<\infty , we say V is Finite-Dimensional. Otherwise V is Infinite-Dimensional.
For example, \dim (\mathbb {R}^{n})=n and \dim (\mathbb {R}[x])=\infty .
Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space. We define an Ordered Basis of V to be a tuple (f_{1},…,f_{n}) of vectors f_{i}\in V for each i=1,…,n such that B=\{f_{1},…,f_{n}\} is a basis of V.

Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space with a well-defined notion of a dot product, let B be a basis of V. We call B an Orthogonal Basis of V if for all f_{i},f_{j}\in B we have f_{i}\cdot f_{j}=0 when i\neq j.

Note: we do not require B to be an ordered basis for us to discuss an orthogonal basis. If we want to stress that B is ordered and orthogonal, then we will speak of it as an "orthogonal ordered basis" of V.

fr:title.text: Coordinates of a vector relative to a basis

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Coordinates of a vector relative to a basis

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space. Let B=(e_{1},…,e_{n}) and C=(f_{1},…,f_{n}) be two ordered bases of V. We may define the Change of Basis Matrix from B to C as the matrix M^{B}_{C}=([e_{1}]_{C}\mid …\mid [e_{n}]_{C}) so any vector v\in V expressed in coordinates [v]_{B} relative to B may give us the coordinates of v relative to C as [v]_{C}=M^{B}_{C}[v]_{B}. The subscript and superscripts are intended to convey an intuition that they behave "like" fractions. (Einstein is credited/blamed for this sort of convention.)

fr:title.text: Change of base matrix and matrix inverse

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Change of base matrix and matrix inverse

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space, let B and C be ordered bases of V. Then the change of basis matrix for these two bases are related by: \mathbf {M}^{C}_{B}=(\mathbf {M}^{B}_{C})^{-1}

fr:title.text: Change of base matrix and matrix inverse

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Change of base matrix and matrix inverse

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space, let B and C be ordered bases of V. Then the change of basis matrix for these two bases are related by: \mathbf {M}^{C}_{B}=(\mathbf {M}^{B}_{C})^{-1}

Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space with a well-defined notion of a dot product. Let x_{1},…,x_{m}\in V be linearly independent vectors. Then we may form m orthonormal vectors (which form an orthonormal ordered basis if \dim (V)=m) by the following algorithm:
Step 1: Set f_{1}=\widehat {x}_{1} to be the unit vector of x_{1}.
Step 2: For each x_{2}, …, x_{m}, compute v_{k} by v_{k}=x_{k}-\sum ^{k-1}_{j=1}(x_{k}\cdot f_{j})f_{j}, and then we set f_{k}=\widehat {v_{k}}=\frac {v_{k}}{\sqrt {v_{k}\cdot v_{k}}}.
This will produce an ordered tuple (f_{1},…,f_{m}) of orthonormal vectors of V.
We can equivalently note that we can use projections to form a bunch of orthogonal vectors:

Let V be a real vector space with a well-defined notion of dot product (or some way to compute the projection of one vector along another). Let u,v\in V. Assume u\neq \vec {0}. We define the Decomposition of v with respect to u as consisting of two vectors of V:

fr:ol.fr:li: The parallel part v^{\parallel }=\mathrm {Proj}_{u}(v), and
The perpedincular part v^{\bot }=v-v^{\parallel }.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be real vector spaces. A Linear Transformation from V to W is a function L\colon V\to W such that for all u,v\in V and coefficients c_{1},c_{2}\in \mathbb {R} we have L(c_{1}u+c_{2}v)=c_{1}L(u)+c_{2}L(v). If further V=W, then we call L a Linear Operator.

Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space. Let u\in V be a nonzero vector u\neq \vec {0}. Then projection along u \mathrm {Proj}_{u}(-) is a linear operator on V. To see this, we check \mathrm {Proj}_{u}(c_{1}v_{1}+c_{2}v_{2})=c_{1}\mathrm {Proj}_{u}(v_{1})+c_{2}\mathrm {Proj}_{u}(v_{2}) for any v_{1},v_{2}\in V due to basic properties of the dot product.

fr:title.text: Translation is not a linear operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Translation is not a linear operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a real vector space. Let u\in V be a nonzero vector u\neq \vec {0}. The function f\colon V\to V defined by f(v)=u+v is not a linear transformation.
To see this, we find f(v+w)=u+(v+w) but f(v)+f(w)=(u+v)+(u+w)=2u+(v+w), and u\neq 2u unless u=\vec {0}. So f cannot possibly be a linear transformation.

Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space. Let \widehat {x}\in V be a unit vector. We define the Householder transformation with respect to \widehat {x} to be the function H_{x}\colon V\to V sending H_{x}(v)=v-(\widehat {x}\cdot v)\widehat {x} which appeared in our discussion of Orthogonal decomposition.
We see that H_{x} is a linear transformation.

fr:title.text: Identity function is a linear operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity function is a linear operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: When we define a new sort of "morphism" (function between gadgets, like linear transformations), it is always good practice to check if the identity function qualifies. Let V be any real vector space. We claim \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{V}\colon V\to V the identity function on V is a linear operator.
Let X and Y be sets, let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We define the Image (or Range) of f to be the subset \mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (f)=f(X)=\{f(x)\in Y\mid x\in X\}.

fr:title.text: Domain and codomain of a function

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Domain and codomain of a function

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X and Y be sets, let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We define:

fr:ol.fr:li: The Domain of f to be the set \mathop {\textrm {dom}}\nolimits (f):=X consisting of the inputs;
The Codomain of f to be the set \mathop {\textrm {cod}}\nolimits (f):=Y consisting of all possible outputs.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Caution: the image is always a subset of the codomain of a function, but the domain could be larger than the image of a function.

Let X and Y be sets, let f\colon X\to Y be a function. If there is a function g\colon Y\to X such that g\circ f=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{X} and f\circ g=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{Y}, where (g\circ f)(x)=g(f(x)) and (f\circ g)(y)=f(g(y)) for x\in X and y\in Y are the compositions of g and f, then we call g the Inverse Function of f.
When an inverse function of f exists, we denote it by f^{-1}.

fr:title.text: Inverse of linear operator is a linear operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse of linear operator is a linear operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a real vector space. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator of V. If there exists an inverse function L^{-1}\colon V\to V, then L^{-1} is a linear operator on V.

More generally, if we have two linear transformations L_{1}\colon V\to W and L_{2}\colon W\to X, then their composition L_{2}\circ L_{1} is a linear transformation from V to X. The result follows from the fact \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{V} and L are linear operators.

Let V and W be finite-dimensional real vector spaces. Let B_{V}=(e_{1},…,e_{m}) and B_{W}=(f_{1},…,f_{n}) be ordered bases for V and W, respectively. Let L\colon V\to W be a linear transformation. Then we define the Matrix of L relative to bases B_{V} and B_{W} to be the n\times m matrix \mathbf {M} such that the j^{\text {th}} column is given by the coordinates [L(e_{j})]_{B_{W}}.

fr:title.text: Coordinates of vector compatible with matrix of a linear transformation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Coordinates of vector compatible with matrix of a linear transformation

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be finite-dimensional real vector spaces. Let B_{V}=(e_{1},…,e_{m}) and B_{W}=(f_{1},…,f_{n}) be ordered bases for V and W, respectively. Let L\colon V\to W be a linear transformation. Let \mathbf {M} be the matrix of L relative to bases B_{V} and B_{W}. Then for any vector v\in V, we have [L(v)]_{B_{W}}=M[v]_{B_{V}}. In other words, "this stuff works together".
Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We say f is Surjective (or that it's a surjection) if for each y\in Y there is at least one x\in X such that f(x)=y.
In other words, the image of f is the codomain of f. Or more vividly, f "covers" all of Y.
Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We say f is injective (or that it's a injection) if for all x_{1},x_{2}\in X such that f(x_{1})=f(x_{2}) we have x_{1}=x_{2}.
Equivalently, if f(x_{1})\neq f(x_{2}), then x_{1}\neq x_{2}.
So no two distinct elements of X are mapped to the same element under f.
We say a function f\colon X\to Y is Bijective (or say f is a bijection) if f is both injective and surjective.
This means for each y\in Y, there exists a unique x\in X such that f(x)=y.

Let L\colon V\to W be a linear transformation of real vector spaces. We define the Kernel of L to be the subset \ker (L)\subseteq V equal to \ker (L)=\{v\in V\mid L(v)=\vec {0}_{W}\}. In other words, the kernel consists of all elements of V which are mapped to the zero vector of W.

fr:title.text: Kernel of linear transformation is a subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kernel of linear transformation is a subspace

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to W be a linear transformation of real vector spaces V and W. Then \ker (L) is a subspace of V.
We see that for any v\in \ker (L) and c\in \mathbb {R} that L(cv)=cL(v) by linearity and cL(v)=c\vec {0}_{W}=\vec {0}_{W}, so cv\in \ker (L).
For any u,v\in \ker (L), we see L(u+v)=L(u)+L(v) by linearity, and L(u)+L(v)=\vec {0}_{W}+\vec {0}_{W}=\vec {0}_{W} by definition of the kernel. Hence u+v\in \ker (L).
Hence by the Criteria for a subset being a subspace, we see \ker (L) is a subspace of V.

fr:title.text: Linear transformation is injective iff kernel is trivial subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear transformation is injective iff kernel is trivial subspace

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to W be a linear transformation of real vector spaces. Then L is injective if and only if \ker (L)=0_{V} is the Trivial subspace of V.

The forward direction: assume L is injective. For any v\in V such that v
eq \vec {0}_{V}, we have L(v)
eq L(\vec {0}_{V}) by definition of injective functions, and this means L(v)
eq \vec {0}_{W} by the fact linear transformations map the zero vector to the zero vector.

The backward direction: assume \ker (L)=0_{V}=\{\vec {0}_{V}\}. For any v_{1},v_{2}\in V such that L(v_{1})=L(v_{2}), we will prove v_{1}=v_{2}. First, we see L(v_{1})-L(v_{2})=\vec {0}_{W} and then by linearity, the left-hand side becomes L(v_{1}-v_{2})=\vec {0}_{W}. Then v_{1}-v_{2}\in \ker (L) by definition of the kernel. Then v_{1}-v_{2}\in \{\vec {0}_{V}\}, which means v_{1}-v_{2}=\vec {0}_{V}. Then adding v_{2} to both sides gives us v_{1}=v_{2}, as desired. Hence L is injective.
Let L\colon V\to W be a linear transformation of real vector spaces. Then \dim (\ker (L))+\dim (L(V))=\dim (V).

fr:title.text: Eigenvalue and Eigenvector of linear operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eigenvalue and Eigenvector of linear operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to V be a real linear operator. If there exists a nonzero vector v\in V and a nonzero \lambda \in \mathbb {R} such that L(v)=\lambda v, then we call v the Eigenvector of L with Eigenvalue \lambda .

Let \mathbf {M} be an n\times n matrix with coefficients in the real numbers \mathbb {R} or complex numbers \mathbb {C} (or more generally some Field). If there is an n-column vector v which is the zero vector, and if there is a nonzero number \lambda such that \mathbf {M}v=\lambda v then we call v the Eigenvector of \mathbf {M} with Eigenvalue \lambda .
Let \mathbf {M} be a n\times n matrix over the reals (or some Field). We define the Characteristic Polynomial of \mathbf {M} to be the polynomial p(\lambda )=\det (\mathbf {A}-\lambda \mathbf {I}).

Why is this a good notion? Well, with the eigenstuff for a matrix \mathbf {M}v=\lambda v we have \mathbf {M}v-\lambda v=0. But this is really (\mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I})v=0. Then \mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I} is a linear operator, and we're looking for its kernel. The kernel is nontrivial if the determinant is zero, which means we want to find the values \lambda such that \det (\mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I})=0. But this is precisely the characteristic polynomial as we have defined it.

Let \mathbf {M} be an n\times n matrix. Let \lambda _{1}, …, \lambda _{n} be its eigenvalues. Then the determinant is the product of the eigenvalues of the matrix, i.e., \det (\mathbf {M})=\prod ^{n}_{j=1}\lambda _{j}.

Let \mathbf {M} be an n\times n matrix. Let \lambda _{1}, …, \lambda _{n} be its eigenvalues. Then the trace of \mathbf {M} is just the sum of its eigenvalues of the matrix, i.e., \mathrm {tr}(\mathbf {M})=\sum ^{n}_{j=1}\lambda _{j}.

Let \mathbf {M} be an n\times n matrix. We say \mathbf {M} is Diagonalizable if there exists a diagonal matrix \mathbf {D} such that \mathbf {M}\sim \mathbf {D}, i.e., if there exists an invertible matrix \mathbf {P} such that \mathbf {P}^{-1}\mathbf {D}\mathbf {P}=\mathbf {M}.
Let \mathbf {A} and \mathbf {B} be n\times n matrices. If they are similar to each other \mathbf {A}\sim \mathbf {B}, then they have the same eigenvalues.
Exercise: If two matrices have the same eigenvalues, are they similar to each other?

fr:title.text: Matrix is diagonalizable iff it has linearly independent eigenvectors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrix is diagonalizable iff it has linearly independent eigenvectors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbf {A} be an n\times n matrix. Then \mathbf {A} is diagonalizable if and only if \mathbf {A} has n linearly independent eigenvectors.

fr:title.text: Matrix is diagonalizable when the roots of its characteristic polynomial are unique

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrix is diagonalizable when the roots of its characteristic polynomial are unique

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbf {A} be an n\times n matrix. If the roots of the characteristic polynomial of \mathbf {A} are all distinct (i.e., the set of all roots is a set with n distinct elements), then \mathbf {A} is diagonalizable.

Let \mathbf {A} be a real n\times n matrix. Assume \det (\mathbf {A})\neq 0. Then \mathbf {A} is diagonalizable by an orthogonal matrix \mathbf {P} (i.e., \mathbf {A}=\mathbf {P}\mathbf {D}\mathbf {P}^{-1} where \mathbf {D} is a diagonal matrix and \mathbf {P}^{-1}=\mathbf {P}^{\mathsf {T}}) if and only if \mathbf {A} is symmetric \mathbf {A}=\mathbf {A}^{\mathsf {T}}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Field is traditionally defined as a set F with two binary operators, addition (denoted +) and multiplication (denoted \cdot ), satisfying the field axioms:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity of addition: for all x,y,z\in F, (x+y)+z=x+(y+z)
Commutativity of addition: for all x,y\in F, x+y=y+x
Additive identity: there exists a 0\in F such that for all x\in F we have 0+x=x and x+0=x
Additive inverses: for each x\in F there is a unique y\in F such that x+y=0 and y+x=0; in this case, we usually denote y as (-x)
Associativity of multiplication: for all x,y,z\in F, (x\cdot y)\cdot z=x\cdot (y\cdot z)
Commutativity of multiplication: for all x,y\in F, x\cdot y=y\cdot x
Multiplicative identity: there exists a 1\in F such that for all x\in F we have 1\cdot x=x and x\cdot 1=x
Multiplicative inverses: for each x\in F which is nonzero x\neq 0 there is a unique y\in F such that x\cdot y=1 and y\cdot x=1; usually we denote y as x^{-1}
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: for all x,y,z\in F, we have x\cdot (y+z)=(x\cdot y)+(x\cdot z) and (x+y)\cdot z=(x\cdot z)+(x\cdot y)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that some of these are redundant.
Also note: fields are usually written in blackboard bold, and the generic field is either \mathbb {F} or \Bbbk (since the German word for field is "Körper").

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of real field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Principles of Mathematical Analysis, 1.19

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: There exists an ordered field R which has the Least-Upper-Bound Property. Moreover, R contains the rational numbers \mathbb {Q} as a subfield.
Step 1: Define R as the set of all Dedekind cuts
Step 2: Ordering the Dedekind cuts.
Step 3: The set of Dedekind cuts has the least-upper bound property.
Step 4: Construct addition operator on the set of Dedekind cuts.
Step 5: Addition of Dedekind cuts satisfies the relevant ordered field axioms.
Step 6: Construct multiplication operator on subset of positive Dedekind cuts.
Step 7: Finish constructing mutliplication of Dedekind cuts, and it forms an ordered field.
Step 8: Identify a subset of Dedekind cuts with the rational numbers.
Step 9: The "rational" Dedekind cuts are isomorphic to the field of rational numbers.

Suppose we have two ordered fields R_{1} and R_{2} which both have the Least-Upper-Bound Property and each contain the rational numbers \mathbb {Q} as a subfield. Then there exists an order-preserving field isomorphism f\colon R_{1}\to R_{2}, i.e., R_{1} is isomorphic to R_{2}.
Since the ordered field R with the LUB property and containing \mathbb {Q} is essentially unique, we refer to it as the Real Numbers and write it as \mathbb {R}.
Just a sketch of the proof.

Step 1: the fields R_{1} and R_{2} are both character zero, i.e., there is no n\in \mathbb {N} such that 1_{R} + \cdots + 1_{R}=0 (the sum of n copies of 1_{R} vanishes). This is never true for either R_{1} or R_{2}.
Step 2: \mathbb {Q} is order-dense in R_{i}.
Step 3: Let f_{0}\colon \mathbb {Q}\cap R_{1}\to R_{2} be a function taking \mathbb {Q} to \mathbb {Q} in the sense that if q\in R_{1}\cap \mathbb {Q}, then f_{0}(q)=q.
We extend this f_{0} to f\colon R_{1}\to R_{2} by f(r)=\sup \{f(q)\mid q<r\} for all r\in R_{1}. Then by the order-density of \mathbb {Q}, this f is an order isomorphism.
Step 4: The f we just constructed is a field isomorphism.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Archimedean Property of Reals
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Principles of Mathematical Analysis, 1.20(a)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let x\in \mathbb {R}, y\in \mathbb {R}, and x>0. Then there exists a positive integer n such that nx>y.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Density of Rationals in Reals
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Principles of Mathematical Analysis, 1.20(b)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let x\in \mathbb {R} and y\in \mathbb {R}. If x<y, then there exists a p\in \mathbb {Q} such that x<p<y.

fr:title.text: Existence of rational roots of positive real numbers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of rational roots of positive real numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Principles of Mathematical Analysis, 1.21

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let x>0 be real and n>0 be an integer. Then there exists exactly one real number y\in \mathbb {R} such that y^{n}=x.
Since this y is unique, we write it as y=x^{1/n} or y=\sqrt [n]{x} and call it the n-th root of x.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of nth roots
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Principles of Mathematical Analysis, 1.21

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let a>0 and b>0 be real numbers. Let n be a positive integer. Then (ab)^{1/n}=a^{1/n}b^{1/n}
