Assume \mathbb {F} contains all the eigenvalues of A. Then there exists a unique n\times n matrix \mathop {\textrm {JCF}}\nolimits (A) called the Jordan Canonical Form of A such that the following all hold:

fr:title.text: Finitely-generated module with relations among generators is not free

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finitely-generated module with relations among generators is not free

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We may want to think of a generating set as synonymous with a Basis of vector space, but this is incorrect when the generating set has relations among the generators.

For example, let \mathbb {F} be a Field, then we could look at R=\mathbb {F}[x,y] as a ring and M=\mathbb {F}[x,y]/(x^{3}+x^{2}-y^{2}) as an R-module where scalar multiplication is given by the canonical morphism and multiplication in M as a ring. Then M is finitely-generated but not free.

fr:title.text: Modules over fields are synonymous with vector spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modules over fields are synonymous with vector spaces

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let M be either a Left Module over \mathbb {F} or a Right Module over \mathbb {F}. Then M is a Vector Space.
Moreover, any vector space over \mathbb {F} is automatically a module over \mathbb {F}.
Consequently, we treat "vector spaces over fields" as synonymous with "modules over fields".

fr:title.text: Ring of formal distributions has zero divisors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring of formal distributions has zero divisors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field (but it could be any commutative ring, however nice you want it). Let x be a formal variable. Consider the Ring of Formal Distributions \mathbb {F}[{[x,x^{-1}]}] which consists of generic formal power series like f(x)=\sum ^{\infty }_{n=-\infty }a_{n}x^{n}. Consider the specific function \delta (x)=\sum _{n\in \mathbb {Z}}x^{n} Then x\delta (x)=\delta (x) so (1-x)\delta (x). But 1-x\neq 0 and \delta (x)\neq 0, so \mathbb {F}[{[x,x^{-1}]}] has zero divisors.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This ring appears when studying Vertex Operator Algebras, a sort of formal model of 1-dimensional quantum field theories.

fr:title.text: Universal property of field of fractions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Universal property of field of fractions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be any Integral domain. Then there exists a unique Field \mathbb {F} (unique up to isomorphism) and an injection i\colon R\hookrightarrow \mathbb {F} such that for all other fields \Bbbk if \varphi \colon R\hookrightarrow \Bbbk , then there exists an extension \overline {\varphi }\colon \mathbb {F}\hookrightarrow \Bbbk such that the following diagram commutes:
We call \mathbb {F} the Ring of Fractions of R.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This can be generalized to any commutative ring; Matsumara calls it the "total quotient ring" (or the "total ring of fractions").

fr:title.text: Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Corollary 7.4.10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then any nonzero Ring morphism from \mathbb {F} into another ring must be an Injective function.
The Kernel of a ring morphism is an ideal. The kernel of a nonzero morphism is a proper ideal, hence must be 0 by Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fields only have trivial ideals
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.4.9(2)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring. Then R is a Field if and only if its only ideals are 0 and R.
We see R is a field iff every nonzero element is a unit (by definition of a field).
(\Longrightarrow ) If R is a field, then every nonzero ideal contains a unit, which means that R is the only nonzero ideal.

(\Longleftarrow ) Suppose the only ideals of R is the trivial ideal and R itself. Let u be any nonzero element of R. Then (u)=R so 1\in (u). Hence there must be some v\in R such that 1=vu (i.e., u is a unit). Therefore every nonzero element of R is a unit, hence R must be a field.

fr:title.text: Ideal is maximal iff quotient ring is field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal is maximal iff quotient ring is field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.4.12

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let M\mathrel {\triangleleft } R be an ideal. Then M is Maximal ideal if and only if the Quotient Ring R/M is a Field.

fr:title.text: Integers modulo a prime form a field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Integers modulo a prime form a field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let p\in \mathbb {N} be a prime number. Then \mathbb {F}_{p}:=\mathbb {Z} / p\mathbb {Z} forms a Field.
Let us write \overline {n} for the element of \mathbb {F}_{p} corresponding to the equivalence class containing n\in \mathbb {Z}.
Claim 1: \mathbb {F}_{p} forms an Abelian group with addition and \overline {0}.
Claim 2: \mathbb {F}_{p} forms a commutative unital ring with multiplication and multiplicative identity \overline {1}.
Claim 3: Every nonzero \overline {n}\in \mathbb {F}_{p} has a multiplicative inverse.

fr:title.text: Maximal ideals of a commutative ring are prime

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Maximal ideals of a commutative ring are prime

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring. If M\mathrel {\triangleleft } R is a Maximal ideal, then M is prime.
Assume M is maximal. Then R/M is a field (since Ideal is maximal iff quotient ring is field). Then R/M is a Field. Then M is prime by Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain.

We have implicitly used binary operators when discussion the algebra of matrices, Fields, Vector Spaces, and so on. Some concrete examples include Matrix Addition, Matrix Subtraction, and Matrix Multiplication.
Unary operators have been infrequently mentioned. For example, the Matrix Transpose is a unary operator on the set of matrices.
Tradition dictates we explicitly formalize the notions of binary and unary operators.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. A Binary Operator (or, more archaically, Law of Composition) is a function \mu \colon X\times X\to X which is various denoted using infixed notation a\star b or a\cdot b or ab (or, if commutative, a+b) for any a,b\in X.

fr:title.text: Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a set. Then X=\mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits (A,A) the Set of all functions from A to A has a binary operator, namely Composition of functions.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Associative binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. We say \mu is Associative if \forall a,b,c\in X\ldotp \mu (a,\mu (b,c))=\mu (\mu (a,b),c)
Examples of associative binary operators we have already seen in Mathematics:

fr:ul.fr:li: If A is a set and X=\mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits (A,A) is the Set of all functions from A to itself, we know Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions. It turns out that Composing functions is associative.
If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then both addition and multiplication is associative.
Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F} has Matrix Multiplication is Associative.

fr:mainmatter.fr:li: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F} can be equipped with the Commutator which is a binary operator denoted [A,B]=AB-BA for any n\times n matrices A and B over \mathbb {F}. fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Commutative binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. We say \mu is Commutative if \forall a,b\in X\ldotp \mu (a,b)=\mu (b,a)
Examples of commutative binary operators we have already seen in Mathematics:

fr:ul.fr:li: If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then both addition and multiplication is commutative.

fr:ul.fr:li: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F}, we see Matrix Multiplication is not commutative.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity element
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. Let e\in X be an element. We say e is a Unit (or identity element) for \mu if \forall a\in X\ldotp \mu (a,e)=a\land \mu (e,a)=a.

fr:title.text: Examples of identity element for a binary operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Examples of identity element for a binary operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Examples of identity elements for binary operators we have already seen in Mathematics:

fr:ul.fr:li: If A is a set and X=\mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits (A,A) is the Set of all functions from A to itself, we know Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions. It turns out that the Identity function is the identity element for the Composition of functions.
If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then its 0 acts as an identity element for addition and 1 acts as an identity element for multiplication.

Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F} we see that Multiplying by Identity Matrix acts like an identity element for matrix multiplication; and also Matrix Addition with Zero Matrix has the zero matrix act like the identity element for matrix addition.

fr:title.text: Commutator of matrices has no identity element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Commutator of matrices has no identity element

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Commutator of matrices over a Field \mathbb {F} (or a suitable ring). It turns out, the commutator has no identity element. If it had one, say \mathbf {E}, then for any matrix \mathbf {A} we would have [\mathbf {E},\mathbf {A}]=\mathbf {A} and by anticommutativity of the commutator [\mathbf {A},\mathbf {E}]=-\mathbf {A}. But then we find the Jacobi Identity fails to hold: [\mathbf {E},[\mathbf {B},\mathbf {C}]] + [\mathbf {B}, [\mathbf {C}, \mathbf {E}]] + [\mathbf {C}, [\mathbf {E}, \mathbf {B}]] = [\mathbf {C},\mathbf {B}]\neq 0.

fr:title.text: Identity element is at most unique

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity element is at most unique

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. Then there exists at most 1 Identity element for \mu in X.
If e_{1}\in A and e_{2}\in A are two possible identity elements, then e_{1}=\mu (e_{1},e_{2})=e_{2}.

fr:title.text: Inverse of an element with respect to a binary operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse of an element with respect to a binary operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a set equipped with a Binary operator \mu with an identity element e\in A, let a\in A. A (Two-Sided) Inverse of a is an element b\in A such that \mu (a,b)=\mu (b,a)=e.

(1) If \mu is an Associative binary operator, then we can just speak of "inverses" of elements without the "two-sided" prefix. This is because the Inverse with respect to an associative binary operator is unique
(2) If there are multiple binary operators on A, then we should specify that b is an inverse of a with respect to \mu .

fr:title.text: Inverse with respect to an associative binary operator is unique

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse with respect to an associative binary operator is unique

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a set, let \mu be an Associative binary operator on A. Let e\in A be the Identity element for \mu . For any element a\in A, there is at most 1 inverse for a with respect to \mu .

fr:title.text: Fields with addition form a commutative group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fields with addition form a commutative group

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. Then \mathbb {F} equipped with its addition operation forms a group where the identity element is the zero \in \mathbb {F}.

fr:title.text: General Linear group of a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: General Linear group of a vector space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. Let V be a Vector Space over \mathbb {F}. We define the General Linear Group on V to be the group \mathop {\textrm {GL}}\nolimits (V) consisting of all invertible linear maps from V to itself, equipped with composition and the identity linear transformation as the identity element.

When we pick an ordered basis B for V and write matrix M(g) relative to B for each linear transformation g\in \mathop {\textrm {GL}}\nolimits (V), then we recover the General Linear Group of matrices over \mathbb {F}.

fr:title.text: Traditional way of teaching abstract algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Traditional way of teaching abstract algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The traditional way we teach undergraduates is by introducing several types of gadgets in abstract algebra in the following order:

fr:ol.fr:li: Initially, there's some discussion of set theory sufficient for developing algebra. This is "time honored tradition" starting with van der Waerden's book.

When the structure-preserving transformations leave something invariant (e.g., Invariant subspaces in linear algebra), composing such transformations also leaves the thing invariant. This is the guiding intuition of what a "symmetry" is, and the "collection of symmetries" is precisely what a "group" is (originally, they were a "group of symmetries" or a symmetry group).

fr:li.fr:p: (a) But we also saw how, e.g., square matrices have a neat algebraic structure with matrix addition and matrix multiplication. They act like a "number system". This is precisely what is studied with number ring (or just a Ring). A sufficiently nice ring is a Field.
(b) We can generalize linear algebra to describe "vector spaces over arbitrary rings", and these are modules.

fr:ol.fr:li: Galois theory is offered as the pinnacle of abstract algebra, connecting group theory to field theory. Honestly, I never understood the excitement behind Galois theory, since the beautiful parts of it are just the representation theory of groups (describing how "the same symmetries appearing in different situations").

fr:title.text: Modern ways to teach abstract algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modern ways to teach abstract algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The more modern approaches to teaching abstract algebra incorporates some degree of category theory into the mix.

Aluffi's Algebra: Chapter 0 is perhaps the most bold attempt to reorganize abstract algebra around category theory entirely. Instead of ending at Galois theory, Aluffi concludes with homological algebra.
Some ideas from the traditional approach (like "groups with operators") turn out to be confused and muddled (which should be replaced with groups acting on other groups).

If I had to teach abstract algebra to undergraduates, I am torn between the traditional approaches (starting from van der Waerden's Moderne Algebra onwards) which I just outlined, and more modern adaptations which wrap everything in the framework of category theory. Aluffi's Algebra: Chapter Zero seemingly attempts a happy medium, and I am unhappy with it.

One fortunate aspect to Forester is that I'm not forced to choose one or the other. I can outline the "traditional" presentation of topics, and the "modern" presentation of topics, and allow the reader to pick which manner of presentation they wish to peruse.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: When we define a Group (or Vector Space or...), we typically have a kind of "template" for the definition which looks like:

html:blockquote.fr:p: A Gadget consists of some stuff (sets or other gadgets like fields) equipped with some structure (functions, subsets, subset families like topologies, or specific elements) such that a bunch of properties (usually equations) hold.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: John Baez and James Dolan were the first to explore this template for definitions. See also Sections 2.4 and 3.1 of Baez and Shulman.

Model theorists typically describe this as a tuple (all the "stuff" and "structure" are crammed together into one tuple) which satisfy some axioms (the "properties"). While this is neat, it lacks some of the desired "inheritance" (like a Field really is an Abelian group with addition, extended with a multiplication operator and a "one" element). Computer Scientists would suggest using a "finite map" instead of a tuple.

There is also some tension between "Mathematical Practice" and what is desirable when formalizing concepts in a proof assistant. For example, we would often want to define a group as a group object internal to the category of sets, but that adds a lot of needless complications to formalizing this in a proof assistant (where we would want as Spartan a structure as possible).

We have covered a lot of ground discussing intermediate linear algebra. There's room for more topics like the Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse and Gershgorin's circle theorem. But these are usually left for numerical linear algebra.

More advanced discussions of linear algebra will also be a core subject of abstract algebra. The second quarter of abstract algebra generalizes linear algebra to different number systems other than Fields.

fr:title.text: Construct multiplication operator on subset of positive Dedekind cuts

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Construct multiplication operator on subset of positive Dedekind cuts

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We define 1_{R} to be the set of rational numbers strictly less than 1. We claim this is a Dedekind cuts. It will play the role of 1 in multiplying Dedekind cuts together.

If \alpha \in R and \beta \in R are both positive 0_{R}\subset \alpha and 0_{R}\subset \beta , then we define \alpha \beta to be the set of all p\in \mathbb {Q} such that p\leq rs for some r\in \alpha and s\in \beta with r>0 and s>0.
Then this multiplication operation satisfies all the axioms for the Field restricted to R^{+}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Since \gamma =-(-\gamma ), the axioms for multiplication of a Field holds for R except we need to check distributivity.

Let \alpha ,\beta ,\gamma \in R. Then \alpha (\beta +\gamma )=\alpha \beta +\alpha \gamma . The proof breaks up into cases depending on \alpha >0_{R} or \alpha <0_{R}, and separately \beta >0_{R} or \beta <0_{R}, and \beta +\gamma >0_{R} or \beta +\gamma <0_{R}.

For example, \alpha >0_{R} and \beta <0_{R} and \beta +\gamma >0_{R}. Then \gamma =(\beta +\gamma )+(-\beta ), which means \alpha \gamma =\alpha (\beta +\gamma )+\alpha \cdot (-\beta ) But \alpha \cdot (-\beta )=-(\alpha \beta ). Thus \alpha \beta +\alpha \gamma =\alpha (\beta +\gamma ). The remaining cases are proved similarly.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Orthogonal matrix
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 11.4.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let M be an n\times n matrix over a Field \mathbb {F}. We say M is Orthogonal if M^{\mathsf {T}}=M^{-1}.

Recall Differentiation is a linear operator on space of polynomials. So for a Field \mathbb {F}, the vector space of polynomials \mathbb {F}[z] over \mathbb {F} in unknown z, we have \mathrm {d} /\mathrm {d} z be a linear operator on it. Can we compute the determinant of \mathrm {d} /\mathrm {d} z? That is, can we make sense of \det \left (\frac {\mathrm {d}}{\mathrm {d} z}\right ) in some way? More generally, if we consider any linear differential operator, can we compute its determinant?
Such expressions appear in quantum mechanics and quantum field theory.

fr:title.text: Differentiation is a linear operator on space of polynomials

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Differentiation is a linear operator on space of polynomials

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let \mathbb {F}[z] be the vector space of polynomials with coefficients in \mathbb {F} and in unknown z. Then \frac {\mathrm {d}}{\mathrm {d} z}\colon \mathbb {F}[z]\to \mathbb {F}[z] defined by \frac {\mathrm {d}}{\mathrm {d} z}(a_{0}+a_{1}z+…+a_{n}z^{n})=a_{1}+…+a_{k}kz^{k-1}+…+a_{n}nz^{n-1} is a linear operator on \mathbb {F}[z].

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of the determinant
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 8.2.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer, let A=(a_{ij})\in \mathbb {F}^{n\times n} be an n\times n matrix with entries in the Field \mathbb {F}. Then the following all holds:

fr:ol.fr:li: Determinant of zero matrix is zero: \det (0_{n\times n})=0
Determinant of identity matrix is one: \det {I}=1

Let a_{1},…,a_{n} be the column vectors of A, so A=(a_{1}|…|a_{n}). Then the determinant is a linear function of the columns \det (a_{1}|…|ca_{i}|…|a_{n})=c\det (a_{1}|…|a_{i}|…|a_{n}) for any c\in \mathbb {F}, and \det (a_{1}|…|a_{i}+b_{i}|…|a_{n})=\det (a_{1}|…|a_{i}|…|a_{n})+\det (a_{1}|…|b_{i}|…|a_{n}) for any column vector b_{i}\in \mathbb {F}^{n}.

The determinant is an antisymmetric function of the columns of A: for any \pi \in S_{n}, letting a_{1},…,a_{n} be the column vectors of A, we have \pi (a_{\pi (1)}|…|a_{\pi (n)})=\mathop {\textrm {sgn}}\nolimits (\pi )\det (A).
If A has two identical columns, \det (A)=0
If A has a column of zeroes, \det (A)=0
For any B\in \mathbb {F}^{n\times n}, \det (AB)=\det (A)\det (B)
If A is a triangular matrix, then \det (A)=\prod ^{n}_{i=1}a_{i,i} is just the product of the diagonal entries.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: When we define a new term in Mathematics, we should prove it is well-defined. What this proof requires depends on what we're defining.

fr:ul.fr:li: A new constant (possibly parametrized by other objects) C defined as satisfying some condition \Phi [C] requires proving (1) its existence (i.e, proving \exists x\ldotp \Phi [x]), and (2) its uniqueness (i.e., \forall x,y\ldotp \Phi [x]\land \Phi [y]\implies x=y).
A new constant C which is defined as abbreviating some complicated expression is usually well-defined, sometimes we need to prove it has the "correct type".
A new species of thing (like a vector space or a Field) should require proving the existence of at least one such gadget.
All other types of definitions (predicates, adjectives, etc.) are well-defined.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: One of the reasons why the "definition" of a set is not really a definition is because we should prove the existence of a set, but that's not possible. It's also why Mathematicians invented axiomatic set theory: presumably there are mathematical objects called "sets" which already exist, and we're trying to specify their behaviour (or some reasonable approximation) using axioms.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector Space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.20
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. A Vector Space over \mathbb {F} consists of a set V equipped with vector addition +\colon V\times V\to V and scalar multiplication \cdot \colon \mathbb {F}\times V\to V such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: for all u,v\in V, we have u+v=v+u
Associativity: for all u,v,w\in V, we have (u+v)+w=u+(v+w)
Additive identity: there exists a \vec {0}\in V such that for all v\in V we have v+\vec {0}=v
Additive inverse: for each v\in V there exists a w\in V such that v+w=\vec {0}
Associativity of scalar multiplication: for all v\in V and a,b\in \mathbb {F}, we have (ab)v=a(bv)
Multiplicative identity: The multiplicative unital element 1\in \mathbb {F} is such that for all v\in V we have 1v=v
Distributivity: for all a,b\in \mathbb {F} and u,v\in V we have a(u+v)=au+av and (a+b)v=av+bv

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Compare this to the definition of a Real vector space from elementary linear algebra. When \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {R}, we call V a real vector space. When \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {C}, we call V a Complex Vector Space.

fr:title.text: Vector space of polynomials is infinite-dimensional

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector space of polynomials is infinite-dimensional
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Example 2.14
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. Then the vector space of polynomials \mathbb {F}[z] is an infinite-dimensional vector space.

Let S\subseteq \mathbb {F}[z] be any finite set, let N=\{\deg (p)\mid p\in S\}. Then consider the smallest positive integer n\in \mathbb {N} which is not n\notin N. Then z^{n}\notin \mathrm {span}(S). So \mathbb {F}[z] cannot be finite-dimensional.
Let \mathbf {M} be a n\times n matrix over the reals (or some Field). We define the Characteristic Polynomial of \mathbf {M} to be the polynomial p(\lambda )=\det (\mathbf {A}-\lambda \mathbf {I}).

Why is this a good notion? Well, with the eigenstuff for a matrix \mathbf {M}v=\lambda v we have \mathbf {M}v-\lambda v=0. But this is really (\mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I})v=0. Then \mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I} is a linear operator, and we're looking for its kernel. The kernel is nontrivial if the determinant is zero, which means we want to find the values \lambda such that \det (\mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I})=0. But this is precisely the characteristic polynomial as we have defined it.

Let \mathbf {M} be an n\times n matrix with coefficients in the real numbers \mathbb {R} or complex numbers \mathbb {C} (or more generally some Field). If there is an n-column vector v which is the zero vector, and if there is a nonzero number \lambda such that \mathbf {M}v=\lambda v then we call v the Eigenvector of \mathbf {M} with Eigenvalue \lambda .
